Translator: Gustavo Rocha
Reviewer: Capa Girl

14.text: Good afternoon, my name is Michelle Rhee,

17.text: I am the former chancellor of the Washington DC schools

20.text: I'm also currently the CEO of an organization called Students First.

25.text: And the whole idea behind Students First is a simple one,

30.text: if you look over the last twenty to thirty years in this country,

34.text: at the decisions that we have been making about education,

37.text: they have largely been driven by special interest groups.

45.text: You've all these organizations that have tremendous resources

50.text: and therefore tremendous influence on how decisions get made.

54.text: So, that's the way the world works.

56.text: The fact those organizations exist is not actually the problem.

60.text: The problem that we face is that there is no organized national interest group

66.text: with the same heft that, say, the teacher's union

68.text: that's advocating on behalf of children in education.

72.text: So, when children are left out of the equation

74.text: and no one is defending what is good and right for them

77.text: and you have all these other special interests

79.text: what you end up with is a landscape that is very skewed towards the adults

84.text: and very skewed away from children.

87.text: So, that's exactly what Students First aims to try to do,

92.text: and make sure that we have millions of members across the country

95.text: that are advocating for what children deserve.

101.text: because I was both the superintendent of a school district

104.text: and now I run this organization, people always say,

106.text: "What's wrong with education in America today?"

112.text: And often times people say, you know,

114.text: "Give us what the biggest issue in education is."

117.text: And I always refuse to answer that question.

120.text: I refuse to answer it because actually what is wrong with our system is pretty complicated

125.text: and when you try to distill it down to just one thing

128.text: then it sort of implies that if you solve that one thing

131.text: you're gonna fix all of the problems,

133.text: when in fact that is actually not true.

135.text: But people don't like taking no for an answer,

138.text: and so usually -- It is the press, the media, they're very persistent

141.text: and they go to me on, it's like, "Come on, tell us what it is!

145.text: It's the teacher's union, isn't it?

147.text: Or the parents, or we don't have enough money?

150.text: Come on, tell us what it is."

152.text: And you've actually probably heard a lot of this too,

155.text: you go to your cocktail parties

157.text: you and your friends sort of bemoaned the state of public education in our country,

162.text: and then inevitably it sort of devolves down into

164.text: what we need to do is invest more in our schools.

169.text: The question is: is that really right?

172.text: So, I'm gonna show you some data,

174.text: the first slide, when Americans are asked how much money

179.text: they think we are spending on public education in America today.

186.text: They think that we spend about four thousand dollar a year per kid.

191.text: The reality is that we spend several times that,

196.text: actually about ten thousand dollar a year.

201.text: and that is not the only disconnect

203.text: because when those same people are asked

206.text: they will very confidently tell you

208.text: that they believe if we spent more money on education

214.text: So take a look at this:

216.text: the red line shows the expenditure growth on education

220.text: over the last few decades in this country

223.text: and the blue line shows our academic achievement levels,

227.text: of our children in both reading and math

231.text: we have grown several times what we are spending

235.text: and yet our children's academic progress

239.text: This creates an incredibly difficult dynamic

246.text: where people are still trying to figure out what to cut in the budgets, etc.

250.text: Because if, for example, in the last few decades

257.text: and the achievement levels had also tripled,

260.text: then you would be able to say, "Ok, if you cut our budget by ten percent

263.text: this is the loss that you are gonna see."

266.text: But we actually can't show that at all,

268.text: in fact, in the last couple of years

269.text: there've been several states that have cut their education budgets

273.text: and seen their academic achievement levels rise

276.text: so we're in this really tough quandary right now

279.text: about -- you know, what the relationship is

287.text: So why is there this disconnect?

290.text: Where is all of this money going?

292.text: If we have grown the amount of money that we are spending so much

296.text: and we haven't seen the results, what's happening?

298.text: So I'm gonna tell you a very quick story from when I was the chancellor in Washington DC.

302.text: In 2007 I took over the Washington DC public schools,

307.text: at the time they were largely known as the most dysfunctional

312.text: and lowest performing school district in the entire nation.

316.text: Just to give a sliver of data to elucidate that for you:

322.text: of all of the 8th graders who were attending school in DC

327.text: in 2007 only 8% of them were on grade level in mathematics

333.text: 8 % -- which means that 92% of our kids

338.text: did not have the skills and knowledge necessary

340.text: to be productive members of society.

343.text: So, it was no surprise that the young upstart mayor

348.text: who had just been elected, his name was Adrian Fenty,

351.text: decided that as his major priority

355.text: he was gonna take on fixing the schools.

358.text: Because his theory was: you cannot have a great city

361.text: without a great public school system.

364.text: So, he decided to introduce legislation

366.text: that would allow him to take over

371.text: And he got the legislation past

372.text: and in June of 2007, as his first act of having control of the schools,

377.text: he nominated me as the city's first school's chancellor.

382.text: Now, I was a 37 year old Korean girl from Toledo, Ohio,

387.text: who had never run a school much less a school district.

391.text: So people were looking at him and saying,

395.text: Why would he think that she is a person

400.text: who can fix the most dysfunctional school district in the country?"

403.text: And so for days the thought that was teeming through everybody's mind was,

409.text: What on God's green Earth is Adrian Fenty thinking?

413.text: And that was pretty much what I was thinking

416.text: as I was sitting in my office

417.text: the first few days of my tenure,

420.text: thinking, where do you start when you have to fix

423.text: something where every single thing is broken essentially?

427.text: So, I was lucky enough to have lots of people who wanted to come in and help

431.text: and a number of these people had actually seen

434.text: what had been going on in the school district for several decades

437.text: and they had lot of thoughts about what needed to change.

440.text: Over and over again in my conversations with them

444.text: what they said to me was, "You have to find out, Michelle,

448.text: where all of the money is going."

450.text: Because we were spending almost more money in Washington DC,

455.text: per child, than any other urban jurisdiction in the country

459.text: yet our results were absolutely abysmal.

461.text: So, when you went into the schools

464.text: you saw teachers who had to buy supplies with their own money,

468.text: it did not feel like one of the richest school districts in the nation.

471.text: So it made sense to us that we would try to figure out where the money was being spent.

475.text: So, I sent my team out,

476.text: I said, you know, go look at every spreadsheet,

480.text: tell me where we're spending the money.

482.text: So, a couple of weeks later my special assistant comes back to me

485.text: and he says: "Ok, I did exactly what you said,

487.text: I looked at all of the largest budget items

489.text: and tried to figure out where they are going."

492.text: He said, "I have found two very interesting things."

497.text: Now, in education speak, interesting is code for whack --(Laughter)

503.text: So, the first thing that he says is,

505.text: "Number one: we are spending about ninety million dollars a year

510.text: transporting a few thousand special education kids through the system."

516.text: So, I do the quick back of the envelope math,

519.text: and it turns out that it's about 18,000 dollars

522.text: per year per kid on transportation.

526.text: So, I said, I don't know anything about running bus routes,

531.text: but I'm pretty sure I can do it for less than 18,000 dollars a year.

533.text: For 18,000 dollars a year you could buy the kid a Saturn the first year,

539.text: and a personal chauffeur for the Saturn every year after that.

544.text: So, I am confident that we can do it more effectively.

547.text: and the good news is that we're gonna be able to take the savings

550.text: and push it down into the classroom

552.text: where it's gonna have more of an impact on kids.

554.text: And he said, "Actually, not so fast."

556.text: See, the problem is that the district had done such a poor job

559.text: of transporting the special needs kids to their schools in the past

562.text: that now we're under a court order, a consent decree

567.text: and there's this court appointed special master,

569.text: and he has the responsibility for transporting the kids to school every day,

574.text: he's allowed to spend as much money as he wants,

577.text: and all we can do at the end of the year is pay the bill.

580.text: We have absolutely no ability to control cost.

584.text: And I said, that is the craziest thing I have ever heard!

588.text: And he said that's because you haven't heard titbit number two -- (Laughter)

592.text: He said i'm trying to figure out where are all these children going.

596.text: Washington DC is only a few square miles wide and long,

601.text: you could be doing laps around the city all day

603.text: and you still shouldn't be able to burn off 18,000 dollars worth of fuel,

607.text: so where is all the money going?

609.text: It turns out that we were not just doing a bad job

613.text: of transporting these special education kids,

616.text: we were doing a very bad job of educating them as well.

619.text: And this sort of culture became

622.text: that parents would sue the school district

625.text: because their kids weren't getting the services and resources that they needed.

628.text: We would inevitably lose that lawsuit,

630.text: because we were, in fact, doing a pretty sucky job

634.text: and then, the court would prescribe a remedy

638.text: and most often that remedy was that they would send them to a private school

642.text: and we would be required to pay the tuition to that private school.

647.text: And it was not just that, but every kid had a different remedy.

650.text: So, you had a situation where you might have a housing complex,

653.text: that had ten special needs kids living in it,

656.text: and each of these ten kids would all be assigned to a different school

661.text: in these far-flung places, in Virginia and in Maryland.

664.text: So you'd have ten different buses roll up in the morning

669.text: and ten different bus matrons who were making sure that the kids are ok on the bus,

672.text: all going in different directions to these far-flung places.

676.text: That was one of the reasons

679.text: that we were spending all of this money and not seeing any results.

683.text: Now, this is actually not just unique to Washington DC.

688.text: If you look at this next slide you will see

690.text: that since the 1970s we have had more than 26 states

696.text: have court mandated, sort of education finance cases,

699.text: that have resulted in really, really dramatic increases to funding,

706.text: And the whole goal of that was to try

708.text: to equalize things and make the education achievement levels

713.text: of minority kids more... equal to where it was for other children.

722.text: If you look at the minority achievement level in these 26 states,

727.text: in fact, a review of three states in particular

730.text: shows that the achievement levels of the minority kids in these three states

735.text: where they had these increases actually didn't even keep up with the national averages.

740.text: This is not just about the courts,

744.text: it is about lots of different special interest groups.

746.text: You have the state governments, you have the federal government,

748.text: you have school board, everybody wants to put in set-asides.

754.text: So, they say, we want some of this money to go to curriculum development,

759.text: we want some of the money to go to this community program,

762.text: we want some of the money to go to textbook adoptions,

764.text: and they mandate these set-asides and what it results in

768.text: is that of the 10,000 dollars that we are spending per child,

772.text: actually only about half of it is going into the classroom

775.text: where we think it's gonna have the most impact,

777.text: the rest of it is going to these other things.

779.text: So, this slide actually jives more with people's perceptions

784.text: of how much money is being spent,

785.text: because that's what they see in the classroom.

788.text: So, let's get to what needs to happen about it.

792.text: We need to stop spending money on things that do not work

796.text: and start putting our money towards the things that do.

801.text: More specifically what that means in a school district

804.text: is that we should set really specific goals

807.text: for what we expect a classroom or a school to achieve,

811.text: we have to give people the freedom

814.text: and the autonomy to make the decisions

816.text: about where those dollars are gonna be best spent to get to that goal.

820.text: Then we have to measure whether or not they met the goal or not,

824.text: and then we have to have some accountabilty,

826.text: so, if you did meet the goal or exceeded the goal

828.text: then we're gonna look at what you did

830.text: and we're gonna share those best practices with others.

832.text: And if you did not meet the goal

833.text: then we're not gonna let you spend the money in the same way.

837.text: But that is not the way that we run things.

840.text: So, in order to change the system

842.text: it's not just gonna require a change with the courts and the federal government.

847.text: It actually also requires a cultural change.

851.text: And let me tell you why. As a parent, and I have two kids,

854.text: I had this perception of what school should look like for my two daughters.

859.text: So when my daughter went to kindergarten,

861.text: I thought, I want a grandmotherly woman

864.text: who has had a long teaching career,

867.text: who will take my daughter on her lap, and read her a book

870.text: and if she's only in the classroom with 15 or 16 other kids,

874.text: that's gonna be better for my child.

876.text: What I don't want is for her to be sitting in front of

879.text: you know, computers, in front of a computer screen

882.text: because that seems cold and rigid and that sort of thing, right?

885.text: So this is what we believe

886.text: we hold as our -- sort of beliefs.

889.text: But the reality actually is that the research shows

894.text: that class size largely doesn't matter.

897.text: If you have a smaller class size versus a larger class size,

899.text: it doesn't have that much impact on a student's achievement levels,

901.text: and the latest data that's coming out from some of these new programs

906.text: that utilize technology pretty heavy in the classroom

909.text: shows very good results for kids

911.text: because you can differentiate for the individual needs of every child.

916.text: So, at the end of the day what we have to do

919.text: is ensure that we are not continuing

923.text: to spend more money and not fix the system

926.text: and expect that we're gonna get a different result.

929.text: What we need to do is something very very different

933.text: we have to reinvigorate the system

935.text: by investing in what works and by innovating.

939.text: So, the bottom line is that the next time you go to a cocktail party

943.text: where you hear your friend Ted say

946.text: that we've gotta spend more money on education to fix it.

951.text: You should say, "Do we, Ted? Do we?"

955.text: Because really what we ought to be doing is

962.text: not over mandating and over prescribing

965.text: where the dollar should be spent.

968.text: That we're innovating around new strategies that can help kids learn

973.text: and that at the end of the day, we should funnel our resources

976.text: to where we know it's working for kids.

979.text: That is surely gonna make you the head of the party.
